title.narrative: Driving a conducive cocoa sector in the Netherlands

description.narrative:
Through the Advocacy for Change programme, we successfully put living income firmly on the agenda of the international cocoa sector. We co-published a paper on Necessary Farm Gate Prices for a Living Income through the VOICE Network. This influenced the 2018 Berlin declaration stating that “the cocoa sector will not be sustainable if farmers are not able to earn a living income”. Advocacy in coalition with the VOICE Network has proven to be an effective way to influence policies. The adoption of the Living Income Differential by Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana, and acceptance by most cocoa and chocolate companies or the upcoming due diligence legislation at the EU level, are examples of policies that Solidaridad contributed to influence. In addition, we co-published with VOICE Network the cocoa barometer; a report about the state of sustainability in the cocoa sector. Each report brings an ever deeper analysis of the issues in the cocoa sector. The 2018 Cocoa Barometer focused on Living Income, the one published in 2020 focused on due diligence legislation; both contributed to putting these topics centerstage in the cocoa sector.
In 2020, the DISCO initiative was launched after a long negotiation process between industry, the Dutch government and CSOs. Solidaridad advocated for a strong ambition on all key focus areas and especially on living income. We are pleased with the achievement of having clear living income commitments in place now for all cocoa beans imported into the Netherlands by 2030, and for all chocolate on the Dutch market by 2025. The Covid-19 pandemic led to a decrease in demand for chocolate which led to cocoa prices depreciation, despite the adoption of the Living Income Differential. In response, Solidaridad advocated for higher farm gate prices to ensure a living income and that “Living Income Reference Prices should be based on the current reality of average cocoa farmers, not on hypothetical future yield scenarios for outlier farmers”. The EU Cocoa Talks that started in 2021 are a new opportunity to influence the EU policies that will shape the (sustainable) future of the cocoa sector. We join the consultations and coordinate our advocacy with other CSOs.

1) living income, 2) transparency & accountability, and 3) certification
As part of the Cocoa Barometer consortium, Solidaridad worked on the development of the Cocoa Barometer. Specifically, we have contributed to the development of two consultation papers on living wage and transparency and accountability. In these papers, we analysed the current situation and provided recommendations to stakeholders on their role in the solution. The papers have been published by the consortium partners via their own media channels as well as through sector news outlets such as Confectionery News. In addition, it has been promoted at several cocoa conferences. Feedback on the papers was collected, which serves as input for the further development of the Barometer. The goal of the barometer is to raise awareness on key bottlenecks in the development of a sustainable cocoa sector and to mobilise brands, standard setters and governments to implement the recommendations made. Unfortunately, due to a delay on the side of the contracted party that would deliver the content, the publication of the Barometer had to be postponed to 2018.

comment.narrative: Joint advocacy efforts of Solidaridad and others focusing on the position of smallholder cocoa farmers and the role of national governments, contributed to the establishment of a living income price differential in the course of 2019 by the governments of Ghana and Ivory Coast. Companies and industry organizations announced to pay the Ghana/CDI living income differential. Together with the VOICE network, Solidaridad advocated for a living wage for cocoa farmers. As a result RA/UTZ announced a mandatory cash premium to be implemented in the near future.
